message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest mucopolysaccharidosis. Among the options, only Mannose is a substrate for the enzyme that is defective in mucopolysaccharidosis. This enzyme deficiency leads to an accumulation of glycosaminoglycans, causing the symptoms observed in the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of mucopolysaccharidosis. Among the options, only Mannose is a substrate for the enzyme that is defective in patients with mucopolysaccharidosis type VII (also known as Sly Syndrome), which results in coarse facial features, restricted joint movement, and respiratory problems. Elevated lysosomal enzymes in the blood also support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest respiratory distress and possible mucopolysaccharidosis. Among the options, only Mannose is a substrate for lysosomal enzymes that are defective in mucopolysaccharidoses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest a diagnosis of mucopolysaccharidosis type II (Hunter syndrome), which is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase, leading to an accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. Among the options, only Mannose is not related to GAG metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of the patient suggest she has a lysosomal storage disorder, and the facial features and restricted joint movement suggest mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS). Among the options, only Mannose is a substrate for MPS, specifically MPS type II, also known as Hunter syndrome. Elevated lysosomal enzymes in the blood suggest they are not being properly broken down and are leaking into the bloodstream.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and symptoms suggest a lysosomal storage disease, and the coarse facial features and restricted joint movement suggest Hurler syndrome, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme α-L-iduronidase. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down mucopolysaccharides, including dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. Among the options, only Mannose is unrelated to mucopolysaccharides and lysosomal enzymes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest infantile Pompe disease, which is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-glucosidase (GAA) which breaks down glycogen to glucose. Glycogen is stored in lysosomes and thus, the disease is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in the lysosomes. Among the options, only Mannose is a component of glycogen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of respiratory distress and joint restriction along with elevated levels of lysosomal enzymes, suggesting a lysosomal storage disease. Among the options, only Mannose is a substrate related to lysosomal storage diseases. The symptoms and exam findings suggest that the patient may have Hurler syndrome, which is caused by a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase, an enzyme that breaks down dermatan and heparan sulfate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are consistent with a lysosomal storage disorder such as mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS). The presence of restricted joint movement and coarse facial features strongly suggest MPS. Among the options, only Mannose-6-phosphate (M6P) is involved in MPS. M6P is a lysosomal enzyme that helps target the enzyme to the lysosome. Deficiency in M6P causes the enzyme to be secreted rather than targeted to the lysosome, leading to accumulation of lysosomal enzymes in the blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of mucopolysaccharidosis type I (MPS I), which is caused by a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme that breaks down glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). Among the options, only Mannose plays a role in GAG structure, and thus the correct answer is (D).
